item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
An early sketch image from "Lometa". It's based on a grid, and filled one column at a time, cell by cell. For each cell, there's a probability of switching to the next color in a fixed (but random) sequence. When the grid is shrunk to be tiny, this becomes very soft #generative pic.twitter.com/Ro6jGplOnI

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 10, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
An unused sketch from 2018, around when I was working on "Fragments of Vision/Thought" Those works were focused on probability arrangements for getting interesting distributions of color. I liked the energy of this one, but it wasn't quite what I needed! #generative pic.twitter.com/vJswhZfqQM

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 09, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
Detail from a work in progress pic.twitter.com/KNIgMZKgoc

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 08, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
In "Valera", I used repetitive line patterns to break up layers. As a side bonus, when these are stacked with offset tilts, Moiré patterns emerge and add neat secondary effects #generative pic.twitter.com/z5SjwjvQYc

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 07, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
Throwback to Isohedral VII (var 1) from 2016. I spent a few months making work with isohedral tiling patterns as starting points. This was one of the more chill ones from that series pic.twitter.com/SkbnMSQXuE

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 06, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 05, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
The making of "Brownwood", a recently commissioned work over 9ft (3m) tall! This video shows the creation from start to end, one frame per change to the program. Getting the "rough" details of line quality & color just right was my main focus pic.twitter.com/qQwvfsWCLA

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 04, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
Sketch with my custom interface built around triangle subdivision. No undo support + randomization makes this tricky enough that it takes off some of the pressure to be "perfect" when sketching pic.twitter.com/L0wySbDgSG

— (@tylerxhobbs) May 03, 2020

item.title: tylerxhobbs
item.description:
Detail from a WIP on the theme of water. Really pleased with how the randomly offset lines soften the color patches and allow them to blend together pic.twitter.com/J1mOyQ2zjE

item.description:

item.title: kgolid
item.description:
First attempt at a comparison of color palettes, using @kGolid's chromotome collection. 1 hexagon per palette, 1 "block" per color. RGB (bottom: R, top left: G, top right: B). Hard to read, but I like that you can reason about each without being influenced by the actual colors. pic.twitter.com/fZwtxnAnBg

— (@kgolid) February 11, 2020
